text:
We have a learning portal as private content on HubSpot and we would like to let those pages be indexed by search engines but if one clicks on the link on a search result page the target would be the login page. The <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/website-pages/require-member-registration-to-access-private-content#understand-membership-limitations|documentation >says the following:
> Password-protected content won't be included in search engine indexes, but sensitive data won't be encrypted. HubSpot sends a response equivalent to <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/seo/prevent-content-from-appearing-in-search-results?hubs_content=knowledge.HubSpot.com/website-pages/require-member-registration-to-access-private-content&hubs_content-cta=noindex%C2%A0#use-noindex-meta-tags|noindex >for password-protected pages, so search engines won't include the page in the search index, but they can still crawl the URL. To stop search engines from crawling the URL, you can <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/seo/prevent-content-from-appearing-in-search-results?hubs_content=knowledge.HubSpot.com/website-pages/require-member-registration-to-access-private-content&hubs_content-cta=disallow%20it%20in%20your%20robot.txt%20file.|disallow it in your robot.txt file.>
Is there an option to let HubSpot send another response than the one equivalent to _noindex_, or is that a setting that can't be changed? If this can't be changed could you think of a workaround?
